page.text: The purpose of this Safety Study is to identify crash problems, recommend site-specific
countermeasures, and set up reasonable time periods to implement the proposed
countermeasures along US 6 (Water Street) from just west of the signalized intersection at
Maple Leaf Plaza to just west of SR 44 in the City of Chardon, Geauga County. More specifically,
this report is structured to address the recent crash history (54 crashes from 2007 through
2009) and to provide recommendations to alleviate crashes associated with the high rate of
rear end, angle, and injury-related crashes.
This section of US 6 (log point 4.41 – 5.01) has been identified by the Ohio Department of
Transportation as a top crash location in the state based on total crashes, average daily traffic
(ADT), relative change in crashes over time, and crash severity from 2007 – 2009. Specifically,
this section ranked #192 (the lower the number, the higher the priority) on ODOT’s 2009
Highway Safety Program List for non-freeway locations and exhibits a high rate of injury crashes
(slightly greater than 1 in 6 crashes resulted in an injury). The most recent three years of
available crash data (2007 – 2009) will be used for this report.
Based on crash data obtained from ODOT, the most common types of crashes in the study area
are rear end and angle crashes. Rear end crashes are generally occurring at the intersection of
US 6 and Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue. The cause is likely a combination of mild
congestion during peak periods in the day, driver inattention, and the highly commercial nature
Angle crashes are largely occurring at commercial drive locations; however there are no specific
sites with more than five angle crashes over three years.
The proposed improvement phases for this study can be categorized into short-term and
medium-term phases. See section 8.0 Recommendations for more detailed recommendations.
The short-term recommendations for consideration include:
relamping all signals with LED indications,
upgrading signals with black backplates and retroreflective strips,
upgrading signs with highly reflective sheeting,
adding sign post reflectors to warning and specific regulatory signs,
trimming tree that partially blocks eastbound signal on US 6 at Wilson Mills Road/Cherry
The medium-term recommendations for consideration include:
consolidating commercial driveways east of Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue. This can
occur over time as businesses change and/or get redeveloped,
developing an access management plan for US 6 so that when new businesses are
developed along the corridor they can adhere to the standards,
installing a new mast arm signal support for the southbound approach of Cherry Avenue
adding a near right signal head for the northbound approach of Wilson Mills Road at
For medium-term improvements, the estimated construction costs are approximately $40,095
The study section of US 6 (locally known as Water Street) is located in the City of Chardon
within Geauga County, Ohio. The study limits are from log point 4.41 (just west of the
signalized intersection to Maple Leaf Plaza) to log point 5.01 (just west of SR 44). US 6 runs east
to west and is composed of a three lane cross section throughout most of the section (one
eastbound lane, one westbound lane, and a center left turn lane).
US 6 is primarily commercial with some residential near the eastern end of the study area. The
major intersection is Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue, which is signalized. The other
signalized intersections are Maple Leaf Plaza/Autozone and Washington Street. US 6 is
classified as an urban minor arterial and Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue is classified as an
urban collector. All other roads are classified as urban locals. Based on ODOT’s 2010 Traffic
Survey Reports, US 6 has an ADT of 12,290 vehicles per day.
Traffic control signals are mast arm supported. All traffic signals appear to have twelve-inch
incandescent indications and all signalized intersections contain pedestrian signals and
emergency vehicle preemption. Further analysis of the traffic signals is located in Section 5.0
Street lighting and sidewalks are present throughout the
section and curb ramps appear to be ADA compliant. On-street
parking is prohibited everywhere on US 6. The posted speed
Pavement is composed of asphalt and is in good condition.
Pavement markings are generally in good condition with
several locations having new markings as of the most recent
field review. See Appendix A for the Condition Diagram.
DLZ received crash data from ODOT. Data was verified by location and type utilizing OH-1
reports provided. The most recent three years of data available (2007 – 2009) was analyzed for
crash trends and safety issues. Table 1 summarizes the crash data.
Based on crash data obtained from ODOT, the most common type of crash on US 6 was the rear
end crash. Between 2007 and 2009, 24 rear end crashes occurred at the study intersection
(accounting for about 45% of all crashes), four of which caused an injury. Twenty one rear end
The second most frequently occurring crash from 2007 to 2009 within the study section was the
angle crash. Fifteen angle crashes accounted for about 30% of all crashes. Angle crashes most
frequently occurred at drive locations when a vehicle pulled out of a drive onto US 6. For a
detailed breakdown of all crashes, see the crash summary in Appendix B and the collision
Crash rate = 6.69 crashes per million entering vehicles
most crashes occurred between 2 - 4 PM, corresponding to traffic volumes being highest during the PM peak,
half of the crashes occurred on wet, snowy, or icy pavement,
70% of crashes occurring at the Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue intersection occurred on a Friday,
one pedestrian was hit by a vehicle,
DLZ observed the section in February and May of 2011. Observations were made for AM,
midday, and PM peak hours. The PM peak hour contains the highest vehicular volumes. No
significant queues were observed along US 6. Truck traffic was generally light and overall was
observed to be about 2% of total traffic.
There are many driveways in the study area particularly east of Washington Street where the
area is largely residential. The driveways at intersections, namely Wilson Mills Road/Cherry
Avenue, are generally set back from the intersection area and do not appear to be contributing
DLZ obtained signal timings from the City of Chardon through Signal Service Company. The
three signalized intersections within the project area are coordinated. Left-turn
protective/permissive phases are provided for all phases at Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue,
for US 6 phases (eastbound and westbound) at Maple Leaf Plaza, and for the eastbound phase
at Washington Street. Advanced intersection signs were present on US 6 at all signalized
Signal pattern variations are listed below:
Sunday runs 80 sec cycle all day
DLZ conducted four-hour turning movement counts at the intersections of US 6 and Wilson
Mills Road/Cherry Avenue on February 2, 2011. Twenty year traffic projections were provided
by NOACA. Based on their regional model, the projected growth along US 6 within the project
area is 1.09 over twenty years. The resulting 2031 projected ADT is 19,637.
The turning movement count data was used along with the signal timings to analyze level of
The concept of LOS is a qualitative measure of the operation of traffic flow. LOS considers such
factors as speed, travel time, freedom to maneuver, traffic interruptions, driver inconvenience,
safety, and delay. Signalized intersections are measured for average control delay in seconds
per vehicle. Control delay includes initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped
delay, and final deceleration delay. The delay measurement for vehicles at a signalized
intersection is a combination of driver discomfort, driver frustration, and lost travel time.
The LOS rating system as described in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual gives a value of A
through F to each type of roadway facility representing best to worst traffic conditions.

text.i: Table 2- LOS Criteria for Signalized Intersections

page.text: > 10 sec. but not more than 20 sec. per vehicle
> 20 sec. but not more than 35 sec. per vehicle
> 35 sec. but not more than 55 sec. per vehicle
> 55 sec. but not more than 80 sec. per vehicle
DLZ analyzed the existing signal timings and attempted to optimize the timings using Synchro
software. Based on the analysis, the signals are running in an efficient manner and there is no
need to revise the current timings and phasing. Below is a summary of the LOS and delay at US
Existing yellow and all red clearance intervals were checked against guidelines set forth in the
ODOT Traffic Engineering Manual as well as recommendations by the Institute of
Transportation Engineers (ITE). Based on vehicle speeds and intersection dimensions, the
existing yellow and red clearance intervals are sufficient.
A Sheetz gas station was constructed on the southeast corner of US 6 and Wilson Mills
Road/Cherry Avenue within the past two years. The construction involved combining,
consolidating, and relocating drives to improve access management.
Based on field observations, crash data, and analysis of the study section, there are
improvements that can be made to potentially reduce crashes and increase safety.
The largest percentage of crashes within the study area are rear end crashes. Rear end crashes
are centered around the Wilson Mills Road/Cherry Avenue intersection, although there is not
one approach that is particularly high relative to the others. To increase signal visibility, DLZ
recommends adding black backplates with retroreflective strips as well as upgrading signal
indications to LED. More specifically, increasing visibility may be accomplished by improving
signal head placement for the northbound and southbound approaches at US 6 of Wilson Mills
Road and Cherry Avenue, respectively. Consider a near right signal head for the northbound
approach and a longer mast arm for the southbound approach to better align signal heads with
the travel lanes. See the photos below.
For increased visibility of signs, consider upgrading with highly reflective sheeting and adding
sign post reflectors to warning signs and regulatory signs such as stop and yield signs.
Wet, snowy, and icy pavement conditions were present for about half of all crashes, which is
about 15% higher than the average for similar roadways. However, the pavement on US 6 is in
good condition, the posted speed limit is low at 25 MPH, and drainage did not appear to be an
issue. Very few of the OH-1 police reports actually cited weather as a contributing
circumstance, therefore DLZ recommends that these types of crashes continue to be monitored
closely in the future. In the short-term, consider a skid resistance study.
Angle crashes accounted for approximately 30% of all crashes, mainly occurring at drive
locations. The only location with five or more crashes is the McDonalds exit driveway just east
of Cherry Avenue. Five crashes occurred at this drive between 2007 and 2009. There was no
evidence in the field of sight distance limitations and there is little evidence in the OH-1 reports
to determine a potential cause for these crashes.
The section with the highest rate of angle crashes is between Wilson Mills Road and Washing
Street which has numerous commercial drives. DLZ recommends consolidating drives in this
section where feasible to potentially reduce crashes.
Finally, there is a tree in the tree lawn on the north side of US 6 about 200 feet east of Wilson
Mills Road/Cherry Avenue. The tree overhangs the roadway and restricts the sight of the traffic
signal. DLZ recommends trimming this tree to improve sight distance.
Proposed countermeasures can be categorized in three improvement phases, which are the
short-term, medium-term, and long term phases. The short-term phase improvements should
be implemented within one year. Medium-term phase improvements are intended for one to
five years. Long-term improvements are intended for over five years. There are no long-term
Consider relamping all signals with LED indications,
Consider upgrading signals with black backplates and retroreflective strips,
Consider upgrading signs with highly reflective sheeting,
Consider adding sign post reflectors to warning and specific regulatory signs,
Consider conducting a skid resistance study.
Consider consolidating commercial driveways east of Wilson Mills Road/Cherry
Avenue. This can occur over time as businesses change and/or get redeveloped,
If one does not currently exist, consider developing an access management plan
for US 6 so that when new businesses are developed along the corridor they can
Consider a new mast arm signal support for the southbound approach of Cherry
Consider adding a near right signal head for the northbound approach of Wilson
For medium-term improvements, the estimated construction cost is approximately $40,095

text.b: --The "TOTAL" and "AVERAGE" row formulas are set to only use 2007-2009 crash data. If the crash data is not for these three years, the formulas must be modified by the user to calculate the associated year data.

AverageAnnual Benefits = Total Benefits * ADT Factor
